official-title.#text:
To establish a pilot program to improve the management and accountability within the Veterans
			 Health Administration of the Department of Veterans Affairs, to provide
			 oversight of the Veterans Health Administration, and for other purposes.

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

text.#text: During the five-year period beginning on the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , of the following:

text.#text: The management review under paragraph (1) shall include a review, with respect to the

The management structure, including the roles and responsibilities among the various organizational
			 components (local facilities, regional networks, and the central office).

The oversight of core functions, including the extent to which lines of accountability are clearly
			 delineated.
The evaluation plan, operations, and capacity to implement results-based strategic planning.
The extent to which contractors are used and monitored to support core management functions.

Internal communication mechanisms, including expectations for communications, that support the
			 mission.
The setting of priorities and the monitoring of such priorities.
Budgeting and resource allocation processes.
Workforce planning.

Human capital processes, including training activities, to ensure timely hiring and effective
			 retention of a qualified workforce.
Information technology to support core functions and activities.

How each of the matters described in subparagraphs (A) through (J) may differ for rural medical
			 facilities of the

Incentives, including any perverse incentives, affecting employee actions, quality of care, and the
			 provision of services.

Insights from employees and employee representatives about the work environment and the level of
			 engagement of such employees as can be derived from the results of the
			 annual Federal employee survey and other internal surveys administered by

In this section:

term.#tail:
means an approach, also referred to as program theory, program modeling, or theory of change, that
			 articulates the assumptions of the strategy or tactics of a program or
			 activity and how such strategy or tactics relate to the benefits that the
			 program or activity is expected to contribute toward in order to achieve
			 certain goals, objectives or responsibilities, and may include—

text.#text: The term

the mapping of direct and indirect relationships among relevant resources, activities, milestones,
			 outputs, intermediate outcomes, and end outcomes; and

if significant coordination or cooperation with entities external to a program or activity may
			 contribute to achieving the relevant goals, objectives, or
			 responsibilities, the mapping of the roles of entities external to the
			 program or activity.

term.#tail:
means the processes that are used to identify, assess, monitor, mitigate, and report on risks to
			 achieving the missions, goals, and objectives of a department, agency, or
			 program using resources and processes appropriate to the nature of risks
			 and resources available.

text.#text: The

The Veterans’ Bill of Rights described in this subsection is a statement that veterans should have,
			 at a minimum and in addition to the rights covered by section 17.33 of
			 title 38, Code of Federal Regulations, the following rights:

The right to access the highest quality care, including the right to the most appropriate
			 technology and qualified practitioners.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to the health care system of the

text.#text: The right to continuity of care in the transition from the health program of the

The right to receive assistance in understanding the available benefits and services to which the
			 veteran is entitled.

The right to receive a careful explanation of a proposed diagnostic or therapeutic procedure or
			 course of treatment by the appropriate medical practitioner, including
			 with respect to the risks, complications, alternatives, and results.
The right to ask questions concerning health treatment.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
should have, at a minimum, the following rights (to the
			 extent of the eligibility and enrollment of the veteran for such health
			 care):

text.#text:
The Veterans’ Bill of Rights described in this subsection is a statement that veterans who receive
			 health care provided under the laws administered by the

The right to access the highest quality care, including the right to the most appropriate
			 technology and qualified practitioners.
The right to know what rules and regulations apply to patients.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to the health care system of the

text.#text: The right to continuity of care in the transition from the health program of the

The right to receive careful explanation of proposed diagnostic or therapeutic procedures or
			 courses of treatment by the responsible medical personnel, including with
			 respect to risks, complications, alternative health practices, results,
			 information and reasoning for prescribed pain management plans, and a
			 daily review of the medical chart of the patient.

The right for the patient to ask questions and be involved in all decisions regarding the care
			 received by the patient.
The right to a second opinion or change of provider, if available.

The right to know the reason for any change in medical practitioners responsible for the care of
			 the patient.

The right to know the identity and professional status of individuals providing service and to know
			 who is primarily responsible for the care of the patient.

The right to not be transferred to another facility, organization, or department unless the patient
			 receives a complete explanation for the need, was notified of
			 alternatives, and the receiving organization, facility, or department is
			 ready to accept the transfer.

The right to receive considerate, respectful care at all times and under all circumstances with
			 recognition of personal dignity, diversity, and religious, or other
			 spiritual and cultural preferences.

The right, in accordance with relevant provisions of law, to personal and informational
			 confidentiality and privacy in the discussion of the care and management
			 of records of patients.

The right to visitors within the policies of the facility and to be informed of the visitation
			 rights, including any clinically necessary restrictions.
The right to be free from all forms of abuse or harassment.
The right to access protective and advocacy services, when available, and file grievances.
The right to remain free of chemical and physical restraints unless safety requires otherwise.

The right to care provided in a safe and clean setting, free from excessive noise and with
			 sufficient lighting for comfort and safety.
